comments.body: Does moving `--party` after `script` work as well? I expect for users it‚Äôs probably more intuitive in most cases to throw everything at the end.

That doesn't work by default. There's an optparse-applicative option ([`subparserInline`](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/optparse-applicative-0.16.1.0/docs/Options-Applicative.html#v:subparserInline)) to enable this. It's a global switch though. At a quick test it seems to cause issues with other commands. E.g. it breaks `daml start` with 
```
Invalid option `--dar'
Usage: daml run-jar JAR [--logback-config ARG] [ARG]
```

The documentation states
> NOTE: When this option is used, preferences for the subparser which effect the parser behaviour (such as noIntersperse) are ignored.

IIUC this also disables `forwardOptions` which we rely on to forward flags to wrapped executables.

comments.body: Will this work on Windows? Are do we need to send a separate ENTER press?
It should work because of the extra `flush`. The extra `ENTER` just forces the flush on Windows, but we're not checking for an extra `ENTER` to start the rebuild on Windows.

comments.body: This is slightly different to the manual test procedure - do we not want the package.json inside the create-daml-app dir created after `daml new`?

IMO, this is an improvement of the manual test procedure we discussed yesterday. We can even have the `package.json` we use to trick `yarn` into using our packages outside of the project. Doesn't that sound better?
Not sure if it's better or worse, but I didn't know that this package.json would have an effect here since you call `daml codegen ts` in the `create-daml-app` directory.

`daml codegen ts` itself does not care about this itself at all. It calls `yarn install` in `daml-ts`, which then does its magic and searches for a workspace `package.json` somewhere along the path to the root directory.

The advantage of what we're doing here is that we don't need to mess around with the directory produced by `daml new` at all. The only thing we mess around with is tricking `yarn install` into picking up our libraries. In fact, this approach can be used to share a single `node_modules` folder as a cache between multiple test runs without weirdly copying it around. I already have big plans for using this to make the `daml2ts` tests faster.

> I already have big plans for using this to make the `daml2ts` tests faster.

I‚Äôll only approve if they get faster by at least 30x.

We should only measure the sum of all `yarn install` steps for this benchmark. If this change doesn't make it 30x fast, then I'll add more test cases until it does make it 30x faster. And I'll add them each in a separate PR. That's what I call two birds with one stone. ü§ì

comments.body:
Please don‚Äôt add more things to the integration tests that don‚Äôt absolutely need to be there. The integration tests are for testing an installed SDK and commands that rely on that. So it‚Äôs useful to test things like `daml start` that actually shell out to various SDK processes and rely on the assistant for that but it doesn‚Äôt buy us anything here.

The integration tests are already very slow and a nightmare to work with (they rebuild the world, `-p` doesn‚Äôt work, ‚Ä¶). For this test, I would recommend that you add them to `//daml-assistant/daml-helper:tests`.
